comments.commentBody: David's view is worse than stereotypical, it is remarkably ignorant and the obverse of reality.  Hardly any progressives are rich.  Hardly any have penthouses.  Not one is contented with the obscene monster our secretive, invasive, law-breaking, war-starting federal government has become under a succession of Republican and Democratic presidents and Congresses.
One day birds will take their job back and Twitter will be out of business. Their tweet will be real and louder than $12 billion.

Twitter is a great tool for communicating a few words to many people by a few.

But that is not how it is used.

It is a now a way to send a few worlds by many to a few people who keep resending it between themselves.

Everyone can think they are someone, but eventually the truth will weigh in. Ditto for the stock.

If what you're saying is true most of the Wingnuts ought to be rooting for the success of the President's agenda and demanding that their representatives in Washington do everything humanly possible to accommodate it.  The sooner Mr. Obama is disclosed to be the anti-Christ the sooner the Tea Party gets raptured up to Heaven and the rest of us can get on with our lives (or what remains of them).

there's great tension and conflict about adequate pain relief and prescription drug dependence, abuse and addiction.  There are no easy answers.  Requiring the patient to have more frequent doctor visits may help as long as the doctors are not just lazily or reflexively either under or over prescribing.  My heart goes out to sufferers of pain.

"Facebook. the other con job"

Really? How come anyone and everyone who bought it can now sell it for a profit?
With no gun pointed at my head, I think I can safely ignore this one.
Putting aside the question of its dollar value, Twitter is infinitely more useful than Facebook. I think you're describing the Twitter stereotype more than what the service actually is.
What ever happened to the lost art of conversation?

Way, way back when Google was at $80, I thought, along with the army of naysayers, that it was too expensive for an unknown.. It's now over $1K. Same for Baidu, it's Chinese cousin, which went to $700 before a 10:1 split.

Potential has value, although not recognized as such by the Accounting Board, and Twitter has oodles of that.

Conversely, many 'sure things' are in the swamp. It's easy to pick a winner looking back. Chutzpah will rule the day. Just watch!

Have you looked at Amazon.com's stock price lately? That is another firm that is still nowhere near making a profit, yet their stock is approaching $400 a share [it closed at $363.39 today, up more than $40 a share, after they reported that they LOST a penny LESS than projected in the third quarter]! The stock market is indeed irrational most of the time, and there are a great many people funding their retirements on the outcomes of that irrationality. Case in point - take Apple. Brilliant products, the largest cash trove of any traded company out there, the sharpest executive team around, huge successes and yet their stock took a beating over the last year, dropping by 40 percent. Go figure! It is completely irrational, so stop predicting what will happen to Twitter at this juncture because you have NO idea. Just watch. And get ready for a roller coaster ride!

As others have mentioned, no earnings, no timeline for when earning will come. In fact, losses. Valuation is discounted stream of earnings = zero. Or assets - liabilities = ?(not much). FB inclusion in Dow & S&P = large number of funds required to hold regardless of price.
what's a 'libraries'? That a new social media app? I don't get it? Is that like shopping malls? RMF

I recall those as my words, exactly, in 2006. To translate: I was wrong.

Some varied applications:

- You are an aspiring television jokewriter. So you constantly post what you believe to be hilarious everyday insights. If tv shows consider your resume, they also look at your twitter feed. (True).

- You're a food truck with a fanbase, but you can't park in the same spot every day. So you tweet your location to your fans in the morning.

- In the midst of a revolution, you need people to gather in a safe spot. You tweet the location to your fellow revolutionaries.

There are other applications, and I don't know about the monetizing. But its part of today's zeitgeist.
Don't  use twitter, don't understand it, in five years, it will collapse.

The night after Steve Jobs died I scribbled this rough cartoon which was an honest expression of my feelings. It actually became quite popular and I'm told was hung up in Apple.

http://www.yjstudios.com/blog/2011/10/06/steve-jobs-death-cartoon/

It was the feeling of losing a magical friend, part Willy Wonka, and part Thomas Edison, who added an aura of excitement and breathtaking possibility into my youth growing up.

The company that carries on with his work does not have that magic but perhaps they are right in being at peace with that.

The car was around one hundred years ago and it is still our main mode of transportation. The work over the one hundred years since then has been building a network of roads to use it, and refining and adding power - the overall shape and concept remains the same.

I suspect the next step is building the highway, not reinventing the car.

We still have an internet system of dirt roads compared to what our devices are capable of. With high speed constant connections orders of magnitude higher than what we have now we will all have access to incredible computing power without having to drag a miniaturized factory around in our device.

At that point, when everything and everyone, from the poor to the rich will be connected to that system, our world will change in ways I can't begin to imagine.

I don't "do" twitter, but I have gone to twitter.com/ and followed somebody who is typing progress reports on a sporting event. But, I don't see any ads. Where is an ad going to appear on that little message?

Just read interesting New yorker profile on Twitter founder Jack Dorsey; then Twitter for Beginners article in today's Times.  OK, Justin Bieber has 45 mil followers, with Katy Perry and Lady Gaga coming on...really, do we need the 140 character "insights" of them or anyone else, given all the info out there.  I just don't get it and I wouldn't invest a dime other than to reap a quick profit.  That said, Dorsey also created Square, a company with real value that serves a definite need (cell phone credit card reader).  That I would invest in.
I would rather speak as in really tweet than type. Have at it in a nice way.

If there's strong interest in the market for this stock, it's unlikely you'd be able to buy at the IPO.  However, if the stock tanks on debut (ala FB), then sure, you'd be able to buy.  Brokers that get an early allotment of shares will be reserving those shares for their best customers.

#1 you need an existing investment account at a company that will be either running the deal or in what is known as the syndicate. Let's use Charles Schwab as an example. They won't be running the deal but may get stock as part of the syndicate. Your chances of getting stock through them are zilch. They will parcel it out to favored accounts.

If you had an account at Goldman Sachs you might get stock but their account minimums are around $10 million. Other banks involved in the deal may have smaller minimums but you get the picture.

What Twitsy should have done is what Google did - a Dutch Auction. Let everyone bid on shares and set the price. Leave the 7% (out of a billion that's a lot) commission out.

Whatever brokerage you use (Goldman Sachs to Ameritrade), you can enter a "buy" price at the opening and your order will fill if the stock hits that price.  You can revise your price upward if the stock takes off and you want to wait for a retraction at the end of the week or month when the first tranche of sellers takes its profits  if you price it a couple of dollars above the opening and a large institutional investor decides to dump after an initial gain, you will probably get your shares executed promptly.  Unless you are investing a 6-figure amount, it's unlikely that most brokerages will put you at the front of the line.  If you are really determined, then make sure the brokerage account you have is with the banker who is doing the deal.  Happy hunting!  Hang on for the ride.
Does anyone know how I could buy twitter at the IPO price, or is that just for well connected people?  I'm pretty new to the stock market, but would really like to get this stock at IPO price.

Amazon is losing money to corner a market, unless regulators step in, they will wipe out small and local stores.  I am no fan of Facebook but they have been profitable since before their IPO, you should probably look up their numbers before commenting.

Well said, next big drop is when Amazon hits the wall given its irrational business plan of "selling " with no profit margin. Take that business plan to a local bank and see how much money you can borrow ?
This is either the dumbest way of bragging, or not true.
Certainly not enough people to matter.
I can think of but one: The Honorable Bernie Sanders.
Is there anybody left in government who is not a water carrier for the rich.

What Constitution were you looking in Tim? Because it certainly wasn't the U.S. one, where "one citizen, one vote" appears nowhere. It was invented by a liberal activist Supreme Court in Reynolds v. Sims.

"In the name of the Holy and Undivided Trinity and Almighty God, swear and promise on my honor and my conscience, in the hands of our president Juan Pablo Duarte, cooperate with me, life and property to the final separation of the Haitian government and to implement a free and sovereign republic independent of foreign domination which is called Dominican Republic.

This oath was taken by the founding fathers of the dominican republic and many others dominican who fought to liberate the easter part of the island. who would think that 169 years later we will continue fighting now against the peaceful invasion of haiti.

the only part of the law that i disagree is the retroactive to 1929.

if we have  a congress  full of right wing  obstructionist, what do you expect the president  to do? He does not control  the purse strings. We have an entire Republican  party who want to destroy the president and  American government. I have seen it put like this; In order to get the captain, Obama, they are willing to sink the entire ship, the country.

This article says 11.3 million unemployed are suffering from Republican neglect.

Meanwhile, those attacking Obama are saying that far more than double that number are suffering unemployment, as they detail the U-6 numbers, and the people not even included in that because they gave up.

http://www.forbes.com/sites/peterferrara/2012/10/11/obamas-real-unemploy...

Thus, the Republicans know full well the suffering they are not helping. They say it is much bigger than Obama admits. They're right. They are causing far more suffering than Obama accuses them of causing.

We are caught between an Administration that does not want to admit how bad things are, and an opposition that does not help how bad things are and uses it as a cudgel on the Administration.

Meanwhile, all those Americans are still unemployed, even if one side won't count them and the other side won't help.
